paper_title: Topotactic Transformation of Bismuth Oxybromide into Bismuth Tungstate: Bandgap Modulation of Single-Crystalline {001}-Faceted Nanosheets for Enhanced Photocatalytic CO<sub>2</sub> Reduction

catalyst.context: The photocatalytic conversion of CO 2 into energy-rich CH 4 solar fuel is an ideal strategy for future energy generation as it can resolve global warming and imminent energy crisis concurrently.However, the efficiency of this technology is unavoidably hampered by the ineffective generation and utilization of photoinduced charge carriers.In this contribution, we report a facile in situ topotactic transformation approach, where 001-faceted BiOBr nanosheets (BOB-NS) were employed as the starting material for the formation of single-crystalline ultrathin Bi 2 WO 6 nanosheets (BWO-NS).The as-obtained BWO-NS not only preserved the advantageous properties of 2D nanostructure and predominantly exposed 001 facets, but also possessed enlarged specific surface area as a result of sample thickness reduction.In opposed to the commonly observed bandgap broadening when the particle sizes decrease to ultrathin nanoscale owing to the quantum size effect, the developed BWO-NS exhibited a fascinating bandgap narrowing compared to pristine Bi 2 WO 6 nanoplates (BWO-P) synthesized from conventional one-step hydrothermal approach.Moreover, the electronic band positions of BWO-NS were modulated resulting from the ion exchange for reconstruction of energy bands, where BWO-NS demonstrated significant upshifting of CB and VB levels, which are beneficial for photocatalytic reduction applications.This propitious design of BWO-NS through integrating the merits of BOB-NS rendered BWO-NS to exhibit a substantial 2.6-fold and 9.3-fold enhancement of CH 4 production over BOB-NS and BWO-P, respectively.

catalyst.context: All chemicals used in the synthesis of photocatalysts were of analytical grade and used as received without any further purification.Bismuth (III) nitrate pentahydrate (Bi(NO 3 ) 3 The fabrication of BiOBr nanosheets (BOB-NS) has been reported in our previous work. 30In brief, 5 mmol of KBr was dissolved in 80 mL of deionized water and the stoichiometric amount of Bi(NO 3 ) 3 5H 2 O was added slowly into the solution.The pH of the solution was altered to 6 using 2.0 M NaOH.Subsequently, the mixture was stirred vigorously at room temperature for 1 h, then transferred to a 125 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave.The autoclave was kept at 160 o C for 12 h.After completion of reaction, the resulting precipitate was collected and washed repeatedly with ethanol and deionized water.Lastly, the product was dried in an air oven at 60 o C for 12 h. The Bi 2 WO 6 nanosheets (BWO-NS) with single-crystallinity and dominantly exposed 001 facets were formed from a hydrothermal anion exchange treatment involving metathesis reaction. Prior to the hydrothermal process, 1.5 mmol of the as-developed BOB-NS was dispersed in 120 mL of aqueous solution containing 1 mmol of Na 2 WO 4 2H 2 O.The mixture was stirred for 30 min at room temperature.Subsequently, the mixture solution was transferred to a 200 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was maintained at 140 o C for 12 h under autogenous pressure.Upon completion of reaction, the autoclave was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature.Then, the precipitate was collected by filtration and washed repeatedly with ethanol and deionized water for several times.Finally, the obtained product was dried in an air oven at 60 o C for 12 h. For comparison, pristine Bi 2 WO 6 nanoplates (BWO-P) were prepared through one-step hydrothermal process without using BiOBr as starting material.Briefly, 1 mmol of Na 2 WO 4 2H 2 O was dissolved in 30 mL of deionized water and the solution was added dropwise into 70 mL of deionized water containing 2 mmol of Bi(NO 3 ) 3 5H 2 O.The mixture solution was stirred vigorously at room temperature for 1 h, then transferred to a 125 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave.The autoclave was maintained at 140 o C for 24 h under autogenous pressure.After completion of reaction, the autoclave was cooled naturally to room temperature and the resulting precipitate was filtered and washed repeatedly with ethanol and deionized water for several times. The final product was subjected to oven drying at 60 o C for 12 h. The crystallographic phase of the as-developed samples was acquired by a X-ray diffractometer equipped with a UV cut-off filter to simulate visible light ( 400 nm). The computations were performed using Cambridge Sequential Total Energy Package (CASTEP) code on the basis of density functional theory (DFT) within the ultrasoft pseudopotential approach. All the proposed geometrical structures were optimized by generalized gradient approximation (GGA) within the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) of exchange-correlation functional.A kinetic energy cut-off of 400 eV and Monkhorst-Pack mesh of 331 were adopted for the geometry optimization and electronic property calculations.The convergence criteria were set as 210 -5 eV/atom for energy, 0.05 eV/A for maximum force, 0.001 GPa for maximum pressure and 0.002 A for maximum displacement. To evaluate the photoactivities of the as-developed photocatalysts, CO 2 photoreduction experiments were performed over all the samples in a continuous gas flow reactor, as delineated in Fig. S1.To mimic natural surroundings, the experiment conditions were maintained at atmospheric pressure and ambient temperature.Prior to the experiments, photocatalysts were uniformly coated on glass rods, and the glass rods were loaded into quartz columns which positioned under light source.Subsequently, high purity CO 2 gas (99.999 ) was directed through H 2 O, and the humidified CO 2 gas was channeled to the quartz columns to allow intimate contact between the reactant gas and coated photocatalysts.The flowrate of gas was maintained at 50 mL/min for 30 min, in order to evacuate excess air from the reactor and also to ensure adsorptiondesorption equilibrium was achieved on the sample surface.Thereafter, the flowrate was reduced to 5 mL/min and kept constant for 8 h under visible light irradiation, which was supplied by a 300W Xenon arc lamp equipped with UV cut-off filter to provide 400 nm.To avoid light interference from the surroundings, the whole reactor setup was enclosed in a black box.The reaction products were collected at every 1 h interval and qualitatively analyzed by online gas chromatography (GC, Agilent 7820A) equipped with a flame ionized detector (FID) and thermal conductivity detector (TCD).The total production yield of CH 4 from the photocatalytic reaction was quantified using Eq.1: (1) where and are the final and initial concentration of CH 4 , is the volumetric flowrate of product gas, and is the amount of photocatalysts used in the experiment.

catalyst.context: In summary, we have demonstrated a facile topotactic transformation approach for the synthesis of ultrathin BWO-NS from BOB-NS.Other than preserving the 2D nanostructure and dominantly exposed 001 facets, the BWO-NS exhibited enlarged specific surface area and improved crystallinity compared to the pristine BWO-P synthesized from one-step hydrothermal process. More importantly, a fascinating bandgap narrowing and upshifting of CB resulting from the mystical effects of ion exchange for reconstruction of energy bands were observed for BWO-NS. Integrating these propitious properties into a single-photocatalyst, BWO-NS exhibited a total CH 4 production yield of 8.02 mol/g after 8 h of reaction under visible light, manifesting a significant 2.6-fold and 9.3-fold improvement of CH 4 production over BOB-NS and BWO-P, respectively.This production yield is impressive for a standalone photocatalyst without involving any cocatalysts, dopants or artificial defects.As a whole, this work delivered an ingenious approach to boost the performance of a standalone photocatalyst through combining the virtues of both photocatalysts, and we believe that our work would bring a step closer towards the rational optimization of efficient photocatalyst design. The computations were performed using Cambridge Sequential Total Energy Package (CASTEP) code on the basis of density functional theory (DFT) within the ultrasoft pseudopotential approach. All the proposed geometrical structures were optimized by generalized gradient approximation (GGA) within the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) of exchange-correlation functional.A kinetic energy cut-off of 400 eV and Monkhorst-Pack mesh of 331 were adopted for the geometry optimization and electronic property calculations.The convergence criteria were set as 210 -5 eV/atom for energy, 0.05 eV/A for maximum force, 0.001 GPa for maximum pressure and 0.002 A for maximum displacement. To evaluate the photoactivities of the as-developed photocatalysts, CO 2 photoreduction experiments were performed over all the samples in a continuous gas flow reactor, as delineated in Fig. S1.To mimic natural surroundings, the experiment conditions were maintained at atmospheric pressure and ambient temperature.Prior to the experiments, photocatalysts were uniformly coated on glass rods, and the glass rods were loaded into quartz columns which positioned under light source.Subsequently, high purity CO 2 gas (99.999 ) was directed through H 2 O, and the humidified CO 2 gas was channeled to the quartz columns to allow intimate contact between the reactant gas and coated photocatalysts.The flowrate of gas was maintained at 50 mL/min for 30 min, in order to evacuate excess air from the reactor and also to ensure adsorptiondesorption equilibrium was achieved on the sample surface.Thereafter, the flowrate was reduced to 5 mL/min and kept constant for 8 h under visible light irradiation, which was supplied by a 300W Xenon arc lamp equipped with UV cut-off filter to provide 400 nm.To avoid light interference from the surroundings, the whole reactor setup was enclosed in a black box.The reaction products were collected at every 1 h interval and qualitatively analyzed by online gas chromatography (GC, Agilent 7820A) equipped with a flame ionized detector (FID) and thermal conductivity detector (TCD).The total production yield of CH 4 from the photocatalytic reaction was quantified using Eq.1: (1) where and are the final and initial concentration of CH 4 , is the volumetric flowrate of product gas, and is the amount of photocatalysts used in the experiment.

lamp.context: In summary, we have demonstrated a facile topotactic transformation approach for the synthesis of ultrathin BWO-NS from BOB-NS.Other than preserving the 2D nanostructure and dominantly exposed 001 facets, the BWO-NS exhibited enlarged specific surface area and improved crystallinity compared to the pristine BWO-P synthesized from one-step hydrothermal process. More importantly, a fascinating bandgap narrowing and upshifting of CB resulting from the mystical effects of ion exchange for reconstruction of energy bands were observed for BWO-NS. Integrating these propitious properties into a single-photocatalyst, BWO-NS exhibited a total CH 4 production yield of 8.02 mol/g after 8 h of reaction under visible light, manifesting a significant 2.6-fold and 9.3-fold improvement of CH 4 production over BOB-NS and BWO-P, respectively.This production yield is impressive for a standalone photocatalyst without involving any cocatalysts, dopants or artificial defects.As a whole, this work delivered an ingenious approach to boost the performance of a standalone photocatalyst through combining the virtues of both photocatalysts, and we believe that our work would bring a step closer towards the rational optimization of efficient photocatalyst design.
